image.altText: Ben Stokes grimaces on the ground

items.synopsis: David Warner falls to Stuart Broad for the 17th time in Tests, but England's battered bowling attack still has work to do. Here's the five things you missed overnight on day two of the third Ashes Test at Headingley.

title.children: Five quick hits — Warner remains Broad's bunny and England's bowling attack limps into day three

image.altText: Centrelink sign.

items.synopsis: Robodebt Commissioner Catherine Holmes has called out how the narrative of welfare recipient vs taxpayer has been used by all sides of politics for decades to generate political populism, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: The meanness at the heart of our politics exposed in Robodebt report

image.altText: A black and white photo of a smiling woman sitting behind a desk

items.synopsis: The next time you book yourself in for a cervical screen, spare a thought for the woman who endured a similar procedure every day for 21 years.

title.children: You probably haven't heard of Mary Papanicolaou — but we owe her (big time) for the Pap test

image.altText: A screenshot from video game Cult of the Lamb showing an anthropomorphic Lamb with devil horns and a red cape.

items.synopsis: You've probably played a video game made by an Australian developer, and you just don't know it. It's an industry that's gone from being almost non-existent after the global financial crisis to pioneering in the space of 15 years.

title.children: How indie developers and mobile games saved Australia's video game industry

image.altText: Young people in white navy uniforms sit at desks, writing on paper with pens. A row of hats on hooks sits on the wall

items.synopsis: At an elite naval school in South Carolina, the first three Australian submariners are graduating from a nuclear training program, in preparation for the first stage of nuclear-powered subs to be delivered under the AUKUS deal.

title.children: Inside 'nuke school', the elite US training ground preparing Australians for AUKUS

image.altText: A large chunk of ice that looks slightly blue at Prospect Point in Antarctica.

items.synopsis: This week has seen Earth break or equal its record for the hottest day on four occasions and set new July highs for ocean temperatures. While in the Antarctic, the amount of sea ice is well below that recorded in previous years.

title.children: Earth smashes records for hottest days, ice the size of WA missing from Antarctic

image.altText: A police officer in uniform and a figure in a full-body white forensics suit stand by a police screen.

items.synopsis: A 20-year-old New South Wales man has been jailed for 14-and-a-half years for a murder committed in broad daylight in a Canberra alleyway in December 2021.

title.children: NSW man sentenced to more than 14 years' jail for daylight murder in Canberra CBD sparked by drug dispute

image.altText: Three flat face masks wrapped in plastic are hung from a string, showing Putin in front, Prigozhin and Lukashenko behind

items.synopsis: Alexander Lukashenko has projected himself as a key negotiator in bringing the Wagner mutiny to an end, but the Belarusian leader now faces a real risk that his peacemaker deal will unravel and leave him with little power and a backyard full of mutinous mercenaries.

title.children: Two weeks after Russia’s mutiny, the situation between Putin and Prigozhin just gets weirder

image.altText: STOKES 55 can be seen on the back of Ben Stokes's shirt as he prepares to walk onto the field to bat

items.synopsis: In a Test match being played at breakneck speed, one thing became clearer than ever — if the Australians are to win the Ashes, they're going to have to go through Ben Stokes.

title.children: If Australia is to win the Ashes, it needs an urgent solution to its Ben Stokes problem

image.altText: A woman lying in bed with medications next to her

items.synopsis: Reported cases of respiratory syncytial virus have surged in Australia, with about 70,000 notified so far this year — but how and when is testing done?

title.children: The number of RSV cases is on the rise — how do you get tested?

image.altText: People standing behind cluster bomb shells.

items.synopsis: The United States confirms it will send cluster munitions to Ukraine to help its military push back Russian forces entrenched along the front lines.

title.children: The US will give Ukraine cluster bombs. Here's why they're being sent now

image.altText: Catherine Holmes speaking on-screen at the Robodebt royal commission

items.synopsis: The Robodebt findings include a lot of legal jargon, as victims ask what the consequences will be for those deemed responsible. Here's a breakdown of how things might play out.

title.children: The Robodebt findings have been handed down – what happens next?

image.altText: A humanoid robot interacting with a man.

items.synopsis: In the world's first robot-human conference in Geneva, robots say they expect to increase in number, help solve global problems, and will not steal humans jobs or rebel.

title.children: Robots in world's first AI press conference say they won't steal jobs or rebel against humans

image.altText: The back of a womans head with dark hair, she is outside the background is blurred but shows trees and a blue sky

items.synopsis: Eliza didn't know where to turn for help when she found out about her husband's sex addiction. Eighteen months on she is still living with the consequences of the revelation and wants others to know they're not alone.

title.children: 'He had this secret life': Eliza's husband had sex with more than a hundred people during their marriage

image.altText: An auctioneer raises his arm, standing on a suburban street in front of a small crowd of people.

items.synopsis: A bunch of people waving their hands on a suburban street might sometimes feel like a chaotic and stressful way to land a property. Here's why economists believe the property auctions which are so common in Sydney and Melbourne are still an "efficient" way to land a fair price.

title.children: Auctions can be chaotic and stressful, so why are Australians so attached to them?

image.altText: Man squats at edge of murky river bank holding a stick and prodding it into the water whilst holding a handgun in his other hand

items.synopsis: There aren't many workplaces that include crocodiles in their work health and safety plans. But in the waterways of the Northern Territory, it is essential.

title.children: An unlikely partnership: How a crocodile catcher helps scientists do their job

image.altText: A composite image of Margot Robbie as Barbie and a performer from Blackpink.

items.synopsis: The communist government of Vietnam has caught the sugary pink Hollywood film and the popular K-pop girl band in the crosshairs of a geopolitical stoush in the South China Sea.

title.children: From Blackpink to Barbie, why is pop culture caught in a geopolitical crossfire?

image.altText: Young man with wavy brown hair, smiles at the camera

items.synopsis: It was just before 1am when Jarrod Davies was escorted out of a nightclub by security. A coroner is investigating why he, and another man three months earlier, died in similar circumstances at the Hobart waterfront.

title.children: Intoxicated and booted out of a waterfront bar, Jarrod's life was about to end

image.altText: A woman watches an array of screens displaying CCTV feeds in a call centre

items.synopsis: A landmark series of inquests examining the domestic violence deaths of four Aboriginal women at the hands of their partners has reached the halfway point. Here's what we've learned.

title.children: Halfway through a domestic violence inquest, the NT coroner is unravelling a system in crisis

image.altText: Christopher O'Connell of Australia celebrates winning match point against Jiri Vesely of Czech Republic in the Men's Singles second round match during day five of The Championships Wimbledon 2023 at All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club on July 07, 2023 in London, England.

items.synopsis: With Alex di Minaur crashing out, Chris O'Connell is the last Australian remaining at Wimbledon, but the 29-year old has hit the form of his career at just the right time.

title.children: A journeyman on the run of his life is the last Aussie left standing at Wimbledon

image.altText: Close up photos of Barry and Aaron around the same age, side-by-side. They look very similar.

items.synopsis: When former ABC Radio presenter Barry Whitehead discovered he had another son he admits he buried his head in his hands and "didn't want to know about it".

title.children: At 68, Barry discovered he had another son and the resemblance was uncanny. But there was a tragic twist

image.altText: A bulldozer pushes shrubs over.

items.synopsis: Land clearing has paused at a controversial housing development in Darwin after 11 people were arrested and an emergency injunction was sought.

title.children: Bulldozers stopped at Lee Point after cultural heritage injunction

image.altText: Kevin Spacey is pictured wearing glasses, a grey suit with a blue shirt and red tie. He looks down. Behind him a blonde woman.

items.synopsis: Kevin Spacey is standing trial in a London court over 12 sexual offences including four men and allegations that date from 2001 to 2013. The trial is expected to last four weeks.

title.children: 'Creepy' and 'snaky': Actor Kevin Spacey is standing trial in London. Here's what you may have missed

image.altText: A Torres Strait Islander man in a brown suit with a bowler hat and magical dust coming off it.

items.synopsis: As the final season of JK Rowling's Harry Potter and the Cursed Child stage production draws to an end in Melbourne, Michael Bani is searching for his next adventure.

title.children: How a former NRL star scored a dream gig in the Harry Potter stage show

image.altText: A women's soccer team wearing dark green poses for a photo before a big game

items.synopsis: Nigeria head coach Randy Waldrum could be sacked two weeks out from the tournament after publicly criticising the federation.

title.children: Matildas' opponents Nigeria in chaos on eve of 2023 Women's World Cup

image.altText: A white man with short brown hair and glasses, wearing a grey hoodie and a cardigan, stands against a graffitied wall

items.synopsis: Having been diagnosed with HIV in the 80s, the Australian artist and queer activist made a crucial alteration to his will that allowed his work to find fame even after he died.

title.children: David McDiarmid died tragically young from AIDS. His friend is making sure his legacy endures

image.altText: Composite graphic of Federal Opposition Leader Peter Dutton and Queensland Opposition Leader David Crisafulli.

items.synopsis: It's come as a surprise to some Queensland LNP members that there's one glaring omission from the motions set to be openly debated at the Liberal National Party's state convention this weekend, writes Rachel Riga.

title.children: Internal division over Path to Treaty expected to boil over at Queensland LNP convention

image.altText: A close up of a dog having its teeth looked at.

items.synopsis: Pet owners around the country are facing difficult choices as the rising cost of living leaves them choosing between their own needs and those of their four-legged friends, as cruelty reports spike.

title.children: Animal cruelty and neglect on the rise as pet owners bitten by cost of living pressures

image.altText: Hands holding a wooden frame bee hive covered in bees

items.synopsis: While bees are proving their worth as an effective side hustle, they're also helping communities in Solomon Islands in the fight against climate change.

title.children: How beekeeping has become an important side hustle for women in one Pacific country

image.altText: Man holding a bag with arms outstretched standing in front of Parliament House building and lake.

items.synopsis: Journalist Nabil Al-Nashar gets excited about things most of his Australian friends take for granted — fair and honest elections, free speech — due to where he came from.

title.children: How an Egyptian boy taught never to criticise government ended up in Canberra holding politicians to account
